content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting ; planning meeting starts now!
(add a :wave: up top to show you’re here)
we have one meeting proposal
burn down tower of P-high issues compiler-team#479
in addition, I think we’ve talked about trying to pre-allocate time to deal with backport nominations, or even beta regressions in general rather
but I think we’ve also decided that dealing with backports/regressions that pile up could be handled by a subgroup in a dedicated meeting
(i.e. @Wesley Wiser , myself, and @simulacrum . At least, that’s worked pretty well in the past.)
there isn’t much of a concrete proposal yet for compiler-team#479
I think in my head, what I was hoping was that before the meeting, the topic owner (probably me) would build up a doc that categorizes the set of P-high issues

pnkfelix said:

in addition, I think we’ve talked about trying to pre-allocate time to deal with backport nominations, or even beta regressions in general rather

The next release is Feb 24, so we should consider scheduling time on Feb 4 or Feb 11 for that.

pnkfelix said:

I think in my head, what I was hoping was that before the meeting, the topic owner (probably me) would build up a doc that categorizes the set of P-high issues

and then the team would collectively go through that document and discuss the plans for the different bugs

Do people here think that would make sense? Or does someone have a different structure to propose? Does it make sense to dedicate a synchronous meeting time slot to this? (It seems to me like people who want to come can attend, and people who are not interested can just not come)
It might be cool to even try to open the discussion of the P-high issues up to broader portion of the community, maybe...

I think it'd be a useful question to ask the extent to which p-{low,med,high} are "actively used" -- prior to aiming to triage them/address them. I think we use them for triage meeting agendas, but not sure if for other things.
you mean in the sense of “do these priorities reflect the reality of how important these things are” ?
no, in the sense of "is someone looking at these labels"
we certainly could also attempt to review a broader set of tickets to try to confirm if the priorities are accurate
Question: who should "own" P-high issues? Is really individuals? Or should it be sub-teams/working groups
when I look at individual tickets or small sets of tickets, I do look at the labels to get an idea of importance
but I do not attempt to review the whole set of all P-high or P-medium issues as a grop
We're also assuming that tickets are properly labelled in the first place :eyes:
right, that was what I was getting at when I said that we could attempt a broader review
at the very least, reviewing the P-high issues would give us an opportunity to downgrade prioirty of some items
Mislabels are not as big a problem as unlabeled important tickets (but maybe this doesn't happen as much?)
Well, a mislabelled important ticket may be worse than an unlabelled important ticket...
but I think we’re pretty conserative about downgrading labels
Do we have a "formal" definition of what each priority means?
I know we have taken stabs at coming up with definitions
I think the only one it's clear for in P-critical
There's also a pretty large backlog of issues that haven't been interacted with in years. (https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+sort%3Aupdated-asc)

I think in reality the practical definition is how the label is used in practice. Which means: P-critical is potential release blocker. Al P-high means is that it will be included in the weekly count at the triage meeting. (And P-high regressions will be considered explicitly at weekly triage meeting). P-medium/P-low is ignored
I don’t think this is ideal, but it is what we’ve done thus far.

Jack Huey said:

Do we have a "formal" definition of what each priority means?

https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/priority-levels.html
oh thank you @Wesley Wiser
In some ways, my attempt to schedule this meeting is me assuming that 1. the definitions in that forge link are accurate and 2. the P-labels are semi-accurate
and thus, I’m vaguely concerned about the number of P-high issues. They are supposed to be things we keep our eye on.
@Jack Huey had a good point, in that some individual sub-teams may actually have a handle on their respective set of P-high issues
I think the exercise of going through the set would still be meaningful. Its just a question of whether we should bother scheduling a friday meeting to talk about them makes sense.
Personally, I think having a sub-team own a P-high issue gives a higher probability that it gets brought up and moved forward
so that seems like the kind of categorization that could be useful
i.e., which P-high issues have a subteam that owns them
and which do not
Whereas P-critical issues are those that really need to be moved forward quickly and needs one person at least to actively monitor it
I think the categorization you alluded to earlier would be helpful and perhaps discussing the categories of issues rather than specific issues themselves would be more useful.
I kind of forgot that this is a planning meeting, not an issue priority meeting :cold_sweat:
so here’s my current thinking: I’m willing to take the time to do the analysis here and write the doc that drives the meeting
I suspect I want/need more than next week to do it
and I kind of would like a partner who will at least be there for me to bounce ideas off of, and read the doc, etc
If we do want to assign P-high issues to sub-teams, that might be a decent meeting
yes I think that could be good outcome
I can help async for sure

pnkfelix said:

and I kind of would like a partner who will at least be there for me to bounce ideas off of, and read the doc, etc

I'd be happy to schedule some time for that !
and to have concrete knowledge of which issues (or just how many) do not have a subteam
Maybe sync if we can schedule it
Okay. When is best for us to aim to have this ready by? January 28th, or February 4th?

Wesley Wiser said:

pnkfelix said:

in addition, I think we’ve talked about trying to pre-allocate time to deal with backport nominations, or even beta regressions in general rather

The next release is Feb 24, so we should consider scheduling time on Feb 4 or Feb 11 for that.

keeping this in mind, I think we should allocate Feb 4th for regression/backport status review
and I’d like to have the P-high status review on January 28th.
Feel free to include me if you so desire
great
Do you think two weeks is enough time?
If its not, then we’ll cancel
I’m okay with that
(i’m also still planning to carve out time to work on perf.rlo UX changes.)
(but that’s not a design meeting issue. I’m just talking about loud, trying to keep myself honest about my plans)

Are people cool with this plan then?

  • January 28th: P-high bonfire
  • February 4th: beta regression/backport status review

And is there anything else anyone wants to bring up?
That seems fine.
If everyone is good with that plan, then I’ll draft a blog post.
if all is well, I’m good with ending the meeting early (i’ve got some child care stuff to take care of).

I've thinking it would be good to try to set some compiler team goals for 2022. But I think the first step there is some kind of survey or something where we can ask what team members are interested in working on this year.
So no meeting yet.
Oh yes, that would be a good idea. Maybe we should figure out a survey soon, and try to get results in time for the next planning meeting?
that’s a really good idea. @Wesley Wiser do you want to own coming up with survey Q’s?
Sure!
Okay. I’m going to step away. Thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!

pnkfelix said:

we certainly could also attempt to review a broader set of tickets to try to confirm if the priorities are accurate

Esteban Küber said:

We're also assuming that tickets are properly labelled in the first place :eyes:

@pnkfelix These are two reasons why ....

and I’d like to have the P-high status review on January 28th.

... I'd like to participate to this advanced triaging meeting (if possible and not an organization burden). I see a lot of room for improvement on my end when trying to prioritize regressions (often times I don't have the context to really provide a balanced judgement).
I may give notice also in wg-prioritization group (maybe someone there might be interested, just my guess).
@apiraino you mean you want to be part of the friday meeting? or do you mean part of the document being prepared for that friday meeting?

The meeting. To listen to your comments about the issues
(if I have time I will read also the document but that's all I can afford to do in terms of time available)
(the doc. will be prepared asynchronously before the meeting - right?)
yes, I started working on it (or at least some analysis) today

pnkfelix said:

In some ways, my attempt to schedule this meeting is me assuming that 1. the definitions in that forge link are accurate and 2. the P-labels are semi-accurate

I'll post some thoughts I have (purely my own perspective, of course). It might also be worthwhile bringing in more of wg-prioritization for discussions about this. I have the highest confidence in apiraino, our lead, more perspectives can hardly hurt.

Generally, each prioritization is commented on by multiple members of the WG. The prioritization that results is a consensus of those that comment. However, we don't really... look at a criteria sheet? I'm pretty sure I've read that at some point in the past, but I don't know the last time I looked at it personally. In practice, discussions are more subjective than that, so one thing a few members have been concerned about is that we could be vulnerable to drift over time.

That being said, I think our prioritization are generally reasonable, and that our use of P-critical more or less aligns with those criteria, though we are probably a bit more restrictive. For instance, an ICE on invalid code is never assigned a P-critical, even if there's no meaningful error. #91206, which is about the most common imaginable such ICE, only got P-high. P-medium would be the norm.

There are also a bunch of factors we consider that go beyond what's on that sheet. For instance, that classification doesn't describe how to deal with performance regressions. The way a performance regression needs to be handled depends greatly on the size of the regression. There are cases where we see regressions that are so bad the code may as well not compile at all, but it's not clear where the cutoff for that is. Additionally, for platform specific problems, we often consider the tier of the platform.

I'd personally kind of like to see a more comprehensive review where both T-compiler and WG-prioritization are involved, and issues of all prioritizations are sampled. Something explicitly focused on ensuring that prioritizations are accurate and useful across the board, beyond just assigning P-high issues. We could make sure that the criteria we use match up with what T-compiler wants, and then update the written documentation to match what we use in practice. That's just an idea I had though, and I in no way speak for the WG, nor have I previously discussed this this with anyone else on it.
I'm not sure I said what I wanted to say well. I felt like I had to post some version of that sooner or later if I ever wanted to communicate my thoughts though.
I definitely appreciate the writeup
